videos.title: Halloween Safety Tip - Trick Or Treat S4 E18
videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

Maria's tips for a great Halloween:

1. Look both ways before crossing the street.
2. Stay with an adult.
3. Stay away from dark places.
4. Wear comfortable shoes.
5. Do not eat candy that has already been opened.

Happy Halloween!

videos.title: EPISODE 3: What Can I Do To Help?
videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

Sydney celebrated her 10th birthday during the COVID-19 outbreak, but instead of getting down, her mind was on what she could do to help other people! Sydney created this video with her mom to prove that we can all help healthcare workers during this time of need. She suggests emailing your teacher or school district to ask if there is any unused PPE (such as gloves or masks) sitting unused in science labs. The place to contact to make a donation is at donateppe.org. You can also call your local health district or regional hospital to find out what is needed in your area.
 
Sydney uses Story Maker at her elementary school in Snohomish, WA and her mother Melissa who teaches Story Maker to Middle School students in Everett, WA. Their series, “Kids Coping with COVID-19,” is meant to ease young minds, as well as arm children with the knowledge to protect themselves and their family.

videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

From the nightly news to our daily personal conversations, one word is on everyone’s minds: germs...germs...germs!

Young Sydney contributed her voice performance and a song to contribute to the power of this animation from Wonder Media to explain what germs are.

We all know that germs are everywhere and it can be scary. The core message here is that we should be conscoius about touching everything: door handles, cell phones, our toys, and especially our face. Wash your hands with soap and water and stay healthy!

videos.title: EPISODE 8: Happy Mothers Day!
videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

Sydney’s Mother’s Day Song:

Wake up, her face helps me start the day,
Tellin’ me it’s all gonna be okay,
It’s my turn to give so much thanks today,
She’s my rock, my friend,
And we have a bond that is meant to last,
So let’s all dance... for the moms we love!

Come home, she greets me with a smile,
Showin’ me her love will last awhile,
It’s her words, her hugs, her sense of style,
She’s my rock, my friend,
And we have a bond that is meant to last,
So let’s all dance... for the moms we love!
For the moms we love...
We love you ‘til the end!

Happy Mother’s Day. We appreciate you so much!

Mothers can make us feel loved and safe all year long, but their strength has been keenly felt during the last few months of change and uncertainty. A mom, Melissa, and her daughters, Sydney and Sienna, wanted to collaborate on a very special message to send love and thanks to all the guardians of our children. Sydney, age 10, voiced and sang in this animation, with lyrics written by her teen sister, Sienna. What a great Mother's Day gift to get to collaborate with her two girls!

videos.title: Happy Mother's Day from WonderGrove (Sing-Along)
videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

Happy Mother's Day from WonderGrove! Mothers can make us feel loved and safe all year long, but their strength has been keenly felt during the past year of change and uncertainty. 

In 2020, Melissa and her daughters, Sydney and Sienna, wanted to collaborate on a very special message to send love and thanks to moms everywhere. Sydney voiced and sang in this animation, with lyrics written by her sister, Sienna. The trio used Wonder Media Story Maker® to create their sing-along video.

Lyrics:

Wake up, her face helps me start the day, 
Tellin’ me it’s all gonna be okay,
It’s my turn to give so much thanks today,  
She’s my rock, my friend,  
And we have a bond that is meant to last,   
So let’s all dance... for the moms we love!  
 
Come home, she greets me with a smile,  
Showin’ me her love will last awhile, 
It’s her words, her hugs, her sense of style,  
She’s my rock, my friend,  
And we have a bond that is meant to last,   
So let’s all dance... for the moms we love! 
For the moms we love... 
We love you ‘til the end! 
  
Happy Mother’s Day. We appreciate you so much! 

-----------------------------------

videos.title: Celebrate National Reading Month - STRIDE
videos.description:
For more social skills lessons, visit https://www.wondergrovesocialskills.com/ and for critical thinking lessons, visit https://habitsofmindkids.com/

“The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you’ll go.” – Dr. Seuss

Encourage your children to put down their phones and pick up a book today with this powerful animation that was made with the Story Maker® Program!
In honor of Dr. Seuss’ birthday, March is designated as National Reading Month – a month to motivate Americans of all ages to read every day. 

Reading is fun and has many benefits, regardless of your age. It’s a key component of education and professional development. It also has immediate and long-lasting health benefits such as increased cognitive function, memory, vocabulary, empathy and decreased levels of stress. 

Click here to learn more: https://www.k12.com/why-k12/leading-with-literacy-elementary-reading-curriculum/

videos.title: A WonderGrove for Birds: How Birds Help Us & The Environment
videos.description:
For more bird videos, visit our website: https://www.wondergrovelearn.net/birds

In this fascinating episode of "A WonderGrove For Birds", Brooke discovers how birds help us in our backyard, patio or apartment balcony!  Tune in to uncover the remarkable ways birds support nature and how you can learn new skills to attract these amazing creatures to your backyard, through an immersive online learning experience.

This environmental science lesson was inspired by Nature’s Best Hope, Young Readers’ Edition (https://www.amazon.com/Natures-Best-Hope-Young-Readers/dp/1643262149) by Douglas W. Tallamy. He is the co-founder of Homegrown National Park® (https://homegrownnationalpark.org/). 

This series was created by Terry Thoren, the former CEO of Klasky Csupo, Inc., the company that created The Wild Thornberrys. Mr. Thoren has a lifelong passion for birds, inspired by nine glorious years as a child making weekend visits to the beautiful 220-acre Sapsucker Woods Sanctuary at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology in Ithaca, NY. 

SUBSCRIBE for more original WonderGrove stories: https://www.youtube.com/user/WonderGroveKids

videos.description:
For more bird science videos, visit our website: https://www.wondergrovelearn.net/birds

In this fascinating episode of "A WonderGrove For Birds", Brooke discovers the wonder of bird nests, from tiny hummingbird nests no bigger than a quarter to robin nests the size of a soup bowl. Explore how birds construct their nests using a variety of materials, from pine needles to strands of spider webs. Learn new skills to assist birds by providing nesting materials and leaving nests undisturbed until fledglings are ready to fly. Tune in and embark on your own journey to welcome and protect our feathered friends, thinking about the future to ensure a healthier planet for the next generations. 

This environmental science lesson was inspired by Nature’s Best Hope, Young Readers’ Edition (https://www.amazon.com/Natures-Best-Hope-Young-Readers/dp/1643262149) by Douglas W. Tallamy. He is the co-founder of Homegrown National Park® (https://homegrownnationalpark.org/ ).

videos.title: A WonderGrove for Birds: Keep Cats Indoors
videos.description:
For more bird science videos, visit our website: https://www.wondergrovelearn.net/birds

In this fascinating episode of "A WonderGrove For Birds", Brooke emphasizes the importance of keeping pet cats indoors to protect native birds. She draws a comparison, likening a bird's fear of cats to how humans would feel encountering a tiger. While acknowledging that cats make wonderful pets, Brooke highlights their predatory nature, which can endanger bird populations. She also points out the risk of cats contracting diseases from wild birds. To address these issues, Brooke suggests alternatives like training cats to walk on leashes or building catios. By keeping cats indoors, both cats and birds can remain safe.

This environmental science lesson was inspired by Nature’s Best Hope, Young Readers’ Edition (https://www.amazon.com/Natures-Best-Hope-Young-Readers/dp/1643262149) by Douglas W. Tallamy. He is the co-founder of Homegrown National Park® (https://homegrownnationalpark.org/ ). 

This series was created by Terry Thoren, the former CEO of Klasky Csupo, Inc., the company that created The Wild Thornberrys. Mr. Thoren has a lifelong passion for birds, inspired by nine glorious years as a child making weekend visits to the beautiful 220-acre Sapsucker Woods Sanctuary at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology in Ithaca, NY. 

The Cornell Lab of Ornithology created 7 Simple Actions to Help Birds. This video was inspired by their action to Keep Cats Indoors to protect birds. The other six simple actions include Make Windows Safer, Reduce Lawn, Plant Natives, Avoid Pesticides, Protect Our Planet from Plastic, Drink Shade-Grown Coffee, and Watch Birds—Share What You See. 

The Cornell Lab of Ornithology works tirelessly on behalf of birds every day of the year.  Their mission is to interpret and conserve the Earth’s biological diversity through research, education, and citizen science focused on birds and nature. We recommend that you visit their website and explore the wonderful learning opportunities they have for children. https://www.birds.cornell.edu/home/

videos.title: A WonderGrove for Birds: Protect Our Planet from Plastic
videos.description:
For more bird science videos, visit our website: https://www.wondergrovelearn.net/birds

In this fascinating episode of "A WonderGrove For Birds", Brooke discusses the environmental issue of trash, particularly plastic, and its harmful effects on birds, which can accidentally ingest it or get tangled in it. She emphasizes the importance of recycling, which gives materials like plastic, paper, and glass a second life. Through a video showing the recycling process, Brooke highlights how recycling is like magic, transforming waste into something new. She encourages viewers to look for the recycling symbol and be mindful of what they put in the recycling bin, as incorrect items can hinder the process. Recycling helps keep the earth clean and safe for all.

This environmental science lesson was inspired by Nature’s Best Hope, Young Readers’ Edition (https://www.amazon.com/Natures-Best-Hope-Young-Readers/dp/1643262149) by Douglas W. Tallamy. He is the co-founder of Homegrown National Park® (https://homegrownnationalpark.org/ ).

videos.title: A WonderGrove for Birds: Make Windows Safer
videos.description:
For more bird science videos, visit our website: https://www.wondergrovelearn.net/birds

In this fascinating episode of "A WonderGrove For Birds", Brooke explains how windows can be dangerous for birds, as millions of birds are injured or killed each year by flying into them. Since birds have eyes on the sides of their heads, their vision differs from humans, and they often mistake reflections of the sky or trees in windows for open space. To prevent this, Brooke suggests adding decals, stickers, or patterns to break up reflections, closing curtains or blinds, and placing bird feeders either very close or far from windows. Additionally, hanging moving objects like ribbons can help warn birds. These simple actions can make windows safer for birds.

This environmental science lesson was inspired by Nature’s Best Hope, Young Readers’ Edition (https://www.amazon.com/Natures-Best-Hope-Young-Readers/dp/1643262149) by Douglas W. Tallamy. He is the co-founder of Homegrown National Park® (https://homegrownnationalpark.org/ ).
